page.title: 12CHURCH IN THEDDINGWORTH
page.content: The 12th Century Church of All Saints stands in a closed churchyard in the centre of the village on the main road. The building is of stone and has a steeple with five bells, the earliest being cast in 1595 & all are in working order. The boundary, also stone, between the road and Church has recently been completely rebuilt by a local builder. The present churchyard was filled in 1890 and there is a churchyard extension opposite the Church which is used for present day burials. Inside the Church there is the Snetzler Organ which was built in 1754 and features colourful paintings inside the panels which cover the pipes, and also a reversed keyboard - black keys white and white keys black. It is still used for services. The Font dates from Norman times and is also still used.
